datafield.subfield: Connection between Stellar Mass Distributions within Galaxies and Quenching Since z = 2

We study the history from $z\sim 2$ to $z\sim 0$ of the stellar mass assembly of quiescent and star-forming galaxies in a spatially resolved fashion. For this purpose, we use multi-wavelength imaging data from the Hubble Space Telescope (HST) over the GOODS fields and the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) for the local population. We present the radial stellar mass surface density profiles of galaxies with ${M}_{* }\gt {10}^{10}\,{M}_{\odot }$, corrected for mass-to-light ratio (${M}_{* }$/L) variations, and derive the half-mass-radius (R ( )m( )), central stellar mass surface density within 1 kpc (${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}$) and surface density at R ( )m( ) (${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{m}$) for star-forming and quiescent galaxies and study their evolution with redshift. At fixed stellar mass, the half-mass sizes of quiescent galaxies increase from $z\sim 2$ to $z\sim 0$ by a factor of $\sim 3-5$, whereas the half-mass sizes of star-forming galaxies increase only slightly, by a factor of ∼2. The central densities ${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}$ of quiescent galaxies decline slightly (by a factor of $\lesssim 1.7$) from $z\sim 2$ to $z\sim 0$, while for star-forming galaxies ${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}$ increases with time, at fixed mass. We show that the central density ${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}$ has a tighter correlation with specific star-formation rate (sSFR) than ${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{m}$ and for all masses and redshifts galaxies with higher central density are more prone to be quenched. Reaching a high central density (${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}\gtrsim {10}^{10}\,{M}_{\odot }\,{\mathrm{kpc}}^{2}$) seems to be a prerequisite for the cessation of star formation, though a causal link between high ${{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}$ and quenching is difficult to prove and their correlation can have a different origin.

Half-mass radii of all types of galaxies are on average smaller that their half-light radii (by \sim 30 \% \mbox{--}50 \%) with a weak dependence on stellar masses

At fixed mass, the average half-mass size of quiescent galaxies increases by a factor of four since z\sim 2 in a similar pace to their half-light radii ({R}_{m}\propto {(1+z)}^{-1.43\pm 0.12} for massive quiescent galaxies). Mass-weighted sizes of star-forming galaxies change very little at fixed mass ({R}_{m}\propto {(1+z)}^{-0.46\pm 0.11} for massive star-forming galaxies)
Star-forming galaxies build up their central densities with cosmic time concurrently with their outer regions. Quiescent galaxies build up most of the stellar mass in their outskirts
Stellar mass central density within 1 kpc of galaxies ({{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}) is better correlated with sSFR than effective surface density at all studied redshift

Galaxies follow a path on the {{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1}-ΔsSFR plane at all masses and are independent of redshift, i.e., galaxies need to build central densities before quenching. Threshold {{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1} depends on redshift and stellar mass
We emphasize that the correlation between {{\rm{\Sigma }}}_{1} and sSFR does not imply a causal link
